state  has  ways  to  allow  otherwise  qualified  persons  to  spend 
upwards  of  40  hours  per  week  outside  their  home  and  in  the 
community.  Tt  thus  may  not,  by  invoking  the  rules  of  its 
waiver  program,  limit  qualified  persons  to  only  12  hours  in 
the  community  each  week.  That  fails  to  “administer  services, 
programs,  and  activities  in  the  most  integrated  setting  appro- 
priate  to  the  needs  of  qualified  individuals  with  disabilities.” 
28  CLLR.  §  35.130(d)}.  Based  on  the  purpose  and  text  of  the 
ADA,  the  text  of  the  integration  mandate,  the  Supreme 
Court's  rationale  in  Olmstead,  and  the  DOT  Guidance,  we  hold 
that  the  integration  mandate  is  implicated  where  the  state’s 
policies  have  either  (1)  segregated  persons  with  disabilities 
within  their  homes,  or  (2)  put  them  at  serious  risk  of  institu- 
tionalization. 
B 
Because  it  thought  that  the  integration  mandate  was  not 
even  implicated  here,  the  district court  did  not reach  the  ques- 
tion  whether  it  was  violated.  We,  however,  must  press  on,  in
  
Nos.  15-2377  &  15-2389  19 
light  of  our  conclusion  that  the  mandate  is  in  play.  On  cross- 
motions  for  summary  jpidgment,  plaintiffs  presented  evi- 
dence  that  they  were  segregated  from  the  community  and 
that  the  state’s  2011  policy  was  to  blame.  Without  challenging 
the  contentions  about  the  degree  of  community  interaction 
plaintiffs  are  receiving,  the  state  presented  evidence  that 
showed,  in  its  view,  that  the  2011  policy  change  was  not  the 
cause  of whatever  segregation  is  occurring. 
1 
We  turn  once  again  to  Olnistead  for  the  proper  way  to  ana- 
lyze  these  arguments.  It set out  a  test for  determining  whether 
the  ADA's  integration  mandate  is  violated: 
(Under  Title  Il  of  the  ADA,  States  are  required 
to  provide  community-based  treatment  for  per- 
sons  with mental  disabilities  when  [1]  the  State’s 
treatment  professionals  determine  that  such 
sons  do  not  oppose  such  treatment,  and  [3]  the 
placement  can  be  reasonably  accommodated, 
taking  into  account  the  resources  available  to 
the  State  and  the  needs  of  others  with  mental 
disabilities. 
Olmstead,  527  U.S.  at  607.  We  have  understood  this  to  be  the 
Court's  last  word  on  the  point.  See  Omega  Healthcare  [nv’rs, 
Inc.  v.  Res-Care,  fic.,  475  F.3d  853,  864  (th  Cir.  2007)  (noting 
that  “Olmstead  stands  for  the  proposition  that  in  order  to 
avoid  violating  the  [ADA],  the  placement  of  individuals  in 
community-based  settings  is  appropriate”  when  the  test  is
  
20  Nos,  15-2377  &  15-2389 
met);  Radaszewski,  383  F.3d  at  608  Moting,  without  clearly  ap- 
plying  the  test,  that  “the  [Olmstead]  Court  agreed”  with  the 
plaintiffs’  formulation  of  it). 
The  first  two  elements  of  the  test  appear  in  Section  ULA  of 
the  Olinstead  decision,  which  commanded  a  majority  of  the 
Court  and  is  thus  binding  on  us.  The  Court  noted  there  that 
(1)  “the  State  may  generally  rely  on  the  reasonable  assess- 
ments  of  ifs  own  professionals  in  determining  whether  an  in- 
dividual  ‘meets  the  essential  eligibility  requirements”  of  the 
program,  and  (2)  that  there  exists  no  “federal  requirement 
that community-based  treatment be  imposed  on  patients  who 
do  not  desire  it.”  Olmstead,  527  US.  at  602. 
Oimstead’s  articulation  of  the  third  element  of  the  test, 
however,  represents  the  thinking  of  only  a  plurality  of  the 
Court.  Those  Justices  addressed  the  question  of  the  level  at 
which  the  “reasonable  modifications”  provision  should  be 
evaluated —thatis,  which  matters  should  be  considered  in  de- 
ciding  whether  a  requirement  to  provide  integrated  care 
would  constitute  a  fundamental  alteration  of  the  state’s  pro- 
gram.  See  28  CPLR.  §  35.130(b)(7).  It  is  clear  that  some  version 
of the  “reasonable  modifications”  provision —and  its  flip  side, 
the  fundamental-alteration  deferise—must  be  taken  into  ac- 
count  before  deciding  that  the  integration  mandate  was  vio- 
lated.  Justice  Stevens,  concurring  in  the  judgment,  thought 
that  the  fundamental-alteration  detense  rested  ultimately  on 
the  facts;  he  thus  saw  no  need  to  delve  into  the  limitations  on 
the  state’s  duty.  See  Olmstead,  527  U.S.  at  607-08  (Stevens,  J, 
concurring  in  part  and  concurring  in  the  judgment).  Justice 
Kennedy,  writing  for  himself  and  Justice  Breyer,  focused  on 
the  need  for  courts  to  defer  to  the  treatment  decisions  of  the 
treating  physicians,  lest  people  who  need  greater  care  are
  
Nos.  15-2377  &  15-2389  Zi 
shoved  out into  the  community  inappropriately.  Id.  at 608-615 
(Kennedy,  J.,  concurring  in  the  judgment). 
As  long  as  we  bear  in  mind  the  cautionary  remarks  of  the 
concurring  Justices,  we  see  nothing  to  prevent  our  use  of  Sec- 
tion  LLB  of  the  plurality’s  opinion  as  a  starting  point.  Its  artic- 
ulation  of  the  “reasonable  modifications”  element  states  a 
sensible  level  at  which  to  analyze  the  question  whether  re- 
quiring  integrated  services  would  “fundamentally  alter”  the 
nature  of  the  programs.  28  C.P.R.  §  35.130(b)(7).  On  the  one 
hand,  a  “substantial[]  mcrease”  in  the  cost  of  a  few  of  plain- 
tiffs’  services  should  not  “defeat  fa]  Title  TD  claim.” 
Radaszewski,  383  F.3d  at  614,  Such  a  holding  would  eviscerate 
the  integration  mandate.  See  id.  (“Tf  every  alteration  in  a  pro- 
gram  or  service  that  required  the  outlay  of  funds  were  tanta- 
mount  to  a  fundamental  alteration,  the  ADA’s  integration 
mandate  would  be  hollow  indeed.”  (quoting  Fisher,  335  F.3d 
at  1183)).  On  the  other hand,  looking  only  at the  cost of chang- 
ing  the  plaintiffs’  care  would  be  unfair  to  the  state  and  fail  to 
give  it  the  leeway  for  which  Justices  Kennedy  and  Breyer 
called,  “If  the  expense  entailed  in  placing  one  or  two  people 
in  a  community-based  treatment  program  is  properly  meas- 
ured  for  reasonableness  against  the  State’s  entire  mental 
health  budget,  itis  unlikely  that  a  State,  relymg  on  the  funda- 
mental-alteration  defense,  could  ever  prevail.”  Olmstead,  527 
US.  at  603  (plurality  opinion). 
By  specifying  that  both  the  “resources  available  to  the 
State”  and  “the  needs  of others  with  mental  disabilities”  must 
be  taken  into  account,  the  plurality’s  test  allows  for  a  sensitive 
balance  between  the  interests  of  the  state  and  the  interests  of 
the  developmentally  disabied  persons.  The  test  also  prevents 
a  state  from  describing  a  program  at  such  a  specific  level  of
  
22  Nos,  15-2377  &  15-2389 
detail  that  literally  any  change  would  result  in  a  “findamen- 
tal”  alteration.  In  the  end,  the  question  under  the  ADA  is  a 
simple  one:  what effect will changing the state’s  practices have 
on  the  provision  of  care  to  the  developmentally  disabled,  tak- 
ing  into  account  the  resources  available  to  the  state  and  the 
need  to  avoid  discrimination? 
The  evaluation  of whether  a  change  would  fundamentally 
alter  the nature of a program should  be holistic.  Here,  the  state 
has  produced  no  evidence  that  anything  approaching  a  fun- 
damental  change  would  occur  if  the  programs  available  to 
these  plaintiffs  were  handled  differently.  We  thus  do  not  re- 
gard  it  as  a  close  case, 
2 
Neither  of the  first  two  elements  of  the  Olmstead  test  is  dis- 
puted  in  our  case.  By  previously  allowing  the  plaintiffs  signif- 
icantly  more  community  interaction,  the  state’s  medical  pro- 
fessionals  have  demonstrated  that  such  activity  is both  appro- 
priate  and  possible.  The  plaintiffs’  purpose  in  this  lawsuit  is 
to  have  this  level  of community-based  service  restored,  under 
whatever  program  umbrella  will  accomplish  that  end.  The 
plaintiffs’ evidence  shows  that  at  present,  using  the  PS  waiver, 
they  can  arrange  for  no  more  than  10  to  12  hours  of  such  ser- 
vices  per  week,  The  affidavits  maintain  that  this  amount  is  in- 
sufficient  either  (1)  to  allow  any  significant  community  inter- 
action  or  (2)  to  prevent  gaps  in  supervision  that  remained  un- 
covered  by  their  caretakers  or  prior-authorization  services. 
The  state  has  offered  nothing  to  support  its  assumption  that 
the  plaintiffs  actually spend  more  time  in  the  community  than 
their  guardians  have  averred.  Plaintiffs  have  also  provided 
evidence  that  a  more  integrated  setting  is  possible:  their  affi- 
davits  state  that  they  were  able  both  to  achieve  significantly
  
Nos.  15-2377  &  15-2389  23 
more  community  interaction  and  prevent  gaps  in  supervision 
under  the  A&D  waiver. 
It  is  the  state’s  burden  to  prove  that  the  proposed  changes 
would  fundamentally  alter  their  programs.  See  Radaszewski, 
383  F.3d  at  611  (citing  28  CER,  §  35,130(b)(7)).  It  has  failed  to 
carry  that  burden  here.  In  fact,  it  did  not  even  argue  that  the 
plaintiffs  seek  fundamental  alteration  of  their  programs.  In- 
stead,  it  contended  that  “itis  not  ‘reasonable’  to  demand  that 
the  State  alter  the  eligibility  requirements  tor  the  A&D  Waiver 
so  as  to  permanently  enshrine  its  error”  in  placing  the  plain- 
tiffs  on  the  waiver  in  the  first  place. 
There  are  several  problems  with  this  argument.  The  first 
is  that  the  plaintiffs  are  not  asking  to  be  put  back  on  the  A&D 
waiver.  While  that  may  be  one  of  the  outcomes  they  will  ac- 
cept,  it  is  rot  the  only  one.  The  second  is  that  the  state’s  logic 
is  circular.  After  all,  the  state  creates  the  waiver  programs,  and 
therefore  those  programs’  eligibility  criteria.  If  the  state’s  own 
criteria  could  prevent the  enforcement of the  integration  man- 
date,  the  mandate  would  be  meaningless.  The  regulation  ad- 
jacent  to  the  “reasonable  modifications”  provision  antici- 
pates—and  directly  contronts—this  problem.  See  26  CER. 
§  35.130(b)(8)  (A  public  entity  shall  not  impose  or  apply  eli- 
gibility  criteria  that  screen  out  or  tend  to  screen  out  an  indi- 
vidual  with  a  disability  or  any  class  of  individuals  with  disa- 
bilities  from  fully  and  equally  enjoying  any  service,  program, 
or  activity,  unless  such  criteria  cari  be  shown  to  be  necessary 
for  the  provision  of  the  service,  program,  or  activity  being  of- 
fered.”).  The  state  has  made  no  showing  that  its  criteria  are 
“necessary  for  the  provision”  of  the  relevant  services  in  this 
case.  It  cannot  avoid  the  integration  mandate  by  binding  its 
hands  in  its  own  red  tape.
  
24  Nos,  15-2377  &  15-2389 
The  third  reason  the  state’s  argument  cannot  prevail  is  the 
most  important:  the  evidence  presented  on  summary  judg- 
ment  shows  that  the  plaintiffs’  demands  are  entirely  reasona- 
ble;  the  state  has  provided  no  evidence  to  the  contrary.  The 
plaintiffs  do  not  demand  a  significant  increase  in  total  ser- 
vices,  but  rather  a  different  apportionment  of  the  two  kinds  of 
services  they  already  receive.  Pricr-authorization  services  do 
not  allow  the  plaintiffs  to  be  taken  into  the  community. 
Waiver  services  do.  Allowing  the  plaintiffs  to  change  their 
“mix”  of prior-authorization  and  waiver services  would  allow 
them  to  participate  more  fully  in  the  community.  According 
to  their  affidavits,  a  relatively  slight  increase  in  total  services 
would  prevent  them  from  being  unsupervised.  The  state  has 
provided  no  evidence  that  the  plaintiffs’  desired  distribution 
of  services  would  significantly  increase  their  cost,  let  alone 
fundamentally  alter  any  programs. 
Finally,  the  state  argues  that  if  should  be  excused  from 
changing  its  waiver  system  because  it  has  a  “comprehensive, 
effectively  working  plan  for  placing  qualified  persons  with 
mental  disabilities  in  less  restrictive  settings,”  and  therefore 
meets  the  reasonable-modification  standard.  Olnistead,  527 
U.S.  at  605,  The  state  is  referring  to  the  process  if  is  using  to 
move  persons  with  disabilities  from  the A&D  waiver  to  the  Fs 
waiver.  That  is  just  what  plaintiffs  are  attacking:  their  evi- 
dence  shows  that  this  “plan”  is  undermining,  not  furthering, 
the  integration  mandate.  Instead  of moving  people  with  disa- 
bilities  to  more  integrated  settings,  the  state’s  plan  is  making 
their  living  arrangements  less  integrated. 
3 
The  plaintiffs  have  provided  evidence  that  before  the  pol- 
icy  change,  they  were  receiving  the  kind  of  services  they
  
Nos.  15-2377  &  15-2389  25 
needed  to  prevent  isolation  or  institutionalization  and  partic- 
ipate  in  the  community  around  them.  They  also  have  pro- 
vided  evidence  that  the  FS  waiver  services  that  they  currently 
receive  are  insufficient  to  allow  more  than  limited  trips  into 
the  community.  They  describe  current  or  future  gaps  in  ser- 
vices  that  plausibly  put  them  at  risk  of  institutionalization. 
It  also  appears,  however,  that  recipients  of  FS  waiver  ser- 
vices  may  choose  how  to  spend  their  allowance.  The  state  ar- 
gues  that  the  PS  waiver  actually  provides  the  plaintiffs  suffi- 
cient waiver  services  to  participate  in  the  community,  but  that 
these  plaintiffs  have  used  the  FS  resources  in  a  way  that  has 
led  to  their  current  isolation.  In  support  of this  contention,  the 
state  has  offered  evidence  that  the  plaintiffs  could  make  dif- 
ferent  choices  that  would  allow  them  more  services  in  the 
community,  It  also  offered  evidence  that  the  Coles  are  using  a 
lower  dollar  amount  of  services  than  they  did  under  the A&D 
waiver,  and  that Maertz’s  situation has  been  influenced  by  the 
fact  that  his  sister  is  the  paid  provider  of  his  waiver  services. 
There  is  therefore  a  dispute  of  material  fact  as  to  whether  the 
state’s  2011  policy  change  caused  the  plaintiffs’  isolation,  and 
summary  judgement  is  inappropriate  on  that  question.  See 
PED.  R.  Civ.  P.  56(a). 
Hi 
The  party  seeking  class  certification  bears  the  burden  of 
showing,  by  a preponderance  of  the  evidence,  that a  proposed 
dure  23.  Messner  v.  Northshore  Univ,  HealthSystem,  669  Fad 
802,  811  (7th  Cir.  2012).  The  district  court’s  decision  whether 
to  certify  a  class  is  reviewed  tor  abuse  of  discretion.  Mullins  v, 
Direct  Digital,  LLC,  795  F.3d  654,  659  (7th  Cir,  2015).  The  plain- 
tiffs  proposed  the  following  class:
  
26  Nos,  15-2377  &  15-2389 
Any  and  all  persons,  current  and  future,  termi- 
nated  from  the  [A&D  waiver]  as  a  result  of  the 
2011  Policy  Change  who  require  more  services 
each  year  than  are  available  through  the  [FS 
waiver]  and  who  are  not  enrolled  in  the  [CTH 
waiver}. 
The  district  court  found  that  the  plaintiffs  failed  all  of  Rule 
23's  criteria.  We  have  serious  reservations  about  this  decision, 
which  strikes  us  as  too  sweeping.  Nonetheless,  we  may  affirm 
on  any  basis  that  fairly  appears  in  the  record.  Ellis  v.  CCA  of 
Tennessee  LLC,  650  E.SGd  640,  647  (7th  Cir.  2011).  Because  the 
class  definition  was  too  vague,  we  find  that  the  district  court 
did  not  abuse  its  discretion  in  denying  class  certification. 
The  vagueness  of  this  definition  arises  from  the  word  “re- 
quire.”  The  question  is  in  what  ways  do  the  potential  class 
members  “require”  more  services  than  available  under  the  FS 
waiver?  Are  they  medically  required?  Required  for  regular 
community  interaction?  Required  so  as  not  to  violate  the  in- 
tegration  mandate?  (The  last  of  these  definitions  would  risk 
making  this  class  an  impermissible  “fail-safe”  class.  See  Mul- 
lins,  795  P.3d  at  660.)  The  class  definition  does  not  say. 
Avoiding  vagueness  is  important  “because  a  court  needs 
to  be  able  to  identify  who  will  receive  notice,  who  will  share 
in  any  recovery,  and  who  will be  bound  by  a judgment.”  Mul- 
lins,  795  F.3d  at  660.  “To  avoid  vagueness,  class  definitions 
generally  need  to  identify  a  particular  group,  harmed  during 
a  particular  time  frame,  ina  particular  location,  in  a  particular 
way.”  Id,  The  proposed  definition  here  sufficiently  identifies 
the  time,  location,  and  manner  of harm,  but we  cannot  say  the 
same  for  the  “particular  group.”  [d.  Without  knowing  how  to
  
Nos.  15-2377  &  15-2389  2s 
sort  between  those  who  were  and  those  who  were  not  de- 
prived  of  services  to  which  they  were  entitled,  we  would  not 
be  able  to  say  who  should  receive  notice,  be  bound  by  the 
judgement,  and,  if the  class  were  to  prevail  on  the  merits,  share 
in  any  recovery.  The  district  court  therefore  did  not  abuse  its 
discretion  in  denying  class  certification. 
IV 
Our  decision  today  does  not  require  the  state  of Indiana  to 
adopt  any  particular  solution  to  make  its  waiver  program 
compliant  with  the  integration  mandate.  If  plaintiffs  prevail 
on  the  merits,  the  district  court,  in  conjunction  with  the  par- 
ties,  may  exercise  its  equitable  powers  to  craft  an  appropriate 
injunction.  But  the  state  cannot  avoid  the  integration  mandate 
by  painting  itself  into  a  corner  and  then  lamenting  the  view. 
The  state  designs,  applies  for,  develops  policies  regarding, 
and  executes  its  waiver  programs.  If  those  programs  in  prac- 
tice  allow  persons  with  disabilities  to  leave  their  homes  only 
12  hours  each  week,  cooping  them  up  the  rest  of  the  time,  or 
render  them  at  serious  risk  of  institutionalization,  then  those 
programs  violate  the  integration  mandate  unless  the  state  can 
show  that  changing  them  would  require  a  fundamental  alter- 
ation  of  its  programs  for  the  disabled. 
Because  the  plaintiffs’  claims  both  fit  within  and,  if  caused 
by  the  state’s  policy,  represent  violations  of  the  integration 
REMAND  for  further  proceedings  consistent  with  this  opinion. 
We  AFFIRM  the  district  court’s  decision  not  to  certify  the  pro- 
posed  class.  Costs  will  be  taxed  against  the  state.

documents.title: Memorandum in Support of Class Certification
documents.text:
Case 1:13-cv-00957-JMS-MJD   Document 4   Filed 06/14/13   Page 1 of 11 PageID #: 80
IN THE 
UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
SOUTHERN DISTRICT OF INDIANA 
INDIANAPOLIS DIVISION 
 
KARLA STEIMEL, on her own behalf and on  )   
behalf of three (3) classes of those similarly  ) 
situated,  ) 
  ) 
  Plaintiffs,  ) 
  )  No. 1:13-cv-00957-JMS-MJD 
  v.  ) 
  ) 
DEBRA MINOTT, in her official capacity as  ) 
Secretary of the Indiana Family and Social  ) 
Services Administration, et al.,  ) 
  )   
  Defendants.  )   
 
MEMORANDUM OF LAW IN SUPPORT OF 
MOTION FOR CLASS CERTIFICATION 
 
INTRODUCTION 
 
Karla  Steimel  in  this  case  is  a  developmentally  disabled  individual  who  is  caught 
between two (2) Medicaid waiver programs operated by the defendants (“the State”).  On the one 
hand, she has spent twelve (12) or fifteen (15) years on a wait-list to receive services through the 
State’s  Community  Integration  and  Habilitation  Waiver  Program  (“CIH  Waiver”)  (formerly 
known as the Developmental Disabilities Waiver Program), only to be notified—along with 
thousands of other persons—that the wait-list for that program was being eliminated in late 2012 
or early 2013 unless she could demonstrate that she met certain restrictive “priority” criteria.  
This elimination of the wait-list occurred without affording Ms. Steimel or other persons an 
opportunity to appeal the State’s decision.  On the other hand, while on the wait-list for the CIH 
Waiver (and since that time), Ms. Steimel has been receiving services through the State’s Aged 
and Disabled Waiver Program (“A&D Waiver”).  However, the State has recently imposed a 
1 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00957-JMS-MJD   Document 4   Filed 06/14/13   Page 2 of 11 PageID #: 81
requirement  on  developmentally  disabled  individuals  receiving  services  through  that  waiver 
whereby they may only continue to receive those services if they required “skilled medical 
needs”  or  skilled  nursing  services—such  as  suctioning,  ventilation,  or  medication 
administration—that  many  such  persons  do  not  require.    In  other  words,  Ms.  Steimel  is 
challenging  generally  applicable  State  policies  that  have  been  applied  to  hundreds,  if  not 
thousands, of similarly situated persons.  As such, this case is clearly suitable for class treatment, 
and three (3) classes should be certified pursuant to Rule 23(a) and (b)(2) of the Federal Rules of 
Civil Procedure. 
CLASS DEFINITIONS 
Putative Class A, which challenges the elimination of the wait-list for the CIH Waiver 
and the implementation of the restrictive “priority criteria,” is defined as follows: 
Any and all persons on the waiting list for Indiana’s Community Integration and 
Habilitation  Medicaid  Waiver  Program  (including  its  predecessor,  the 
Developmental Disabilities Medicaid Waiver Program) as of August 31, 2012, or 
who will be or would otherwise be on the wait-list for that program but for the 
elimination of that wait-list, and who do not meet Indiana’s priority criteria for 
placement  on  that  program  (described  in  paragraph  33  of  the  plaintiffs’ 
complaint). 
 
Putative Class B, which challenges the State’s failure to afford persons an appeals process upon 
the elimination of their positions on the wait-list for the CIH Waiver, is defined as follows: 
Any and all persons on the waiting list for Indiana’s Community Integration and 
Habilitation  Medicaid  Waiver  Program  (including  its  predecessor,  the 
Developmental Disabilities Medicaid Waiver Program) as of August 31, 2012. 
 
And putative Class C, which challenges the requirement that otherwise eligible persons with 
developmental disabilities also demonstrate the need for “skilled medical services” or “skilled 
nursing services” in order to receive services through the A&D Waiver, is defined as follows: 
Any and all persons enrolled in, or who will be enrolled in, Indiana’s Aged and 
Disabled Medicaid Waiver Program and/or its Traumatic Brain Injury Medicaid 
2 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00957-JMS-MJD   Document 4   Filed 06/14/13   Page 3 of 11 PageID #: 82
Waiver Program who (a) are developmentally disabled and/or under age eleven 
(11), (b) do not routinely require skilled nursing services for their conditions, (c) 
meet nursing facility level of care as determined through the use of Indiana’s 
Eligibility Screen (State Form 45528), and (d) are also determined to be eligible 
for services through the Family Supports Medicaid Waiver Program. 
 
A copy of the notification concerning the elimination of the wait-list for the CIH Waiver, which 
was received by the members of Class A and Class B (other than the future members of Class 
A), is attached to the plaintiffs’ complaint as Exhibit 1; the copy of this notification that was 
specifically received by Ms. Steimel is attached to the plaintiffs’ complaint as Exhibit 6; and 
notes from a “Webinar” prepared by the State explaining the changes in these policies is attached 
to the plaintiffs’ complaint as Exhibit 2.  Similar, copies of the policies addressing the change in 
policies for eligibility for the A&D Waiver are attached to the plaintiffs’ complaint as Exhibits 3 
and 4. 
ARGUMENT 
The requirements for certification of a class under the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure 
are clear.  In order for an individual or individuals to sue on behalf of a class, four requirements 
must be met:  
(1) The class must be so numerous that the joinder of all members is impracticable; 
(2) There must be questions of law or fact common to the class; 
(3) The claims or defenses of the representative parties must be typical of the claims or 
defenses of the class; and 
(4) The representative parties must fairly and adequately protect the interests of the class. 
 
FED.  R.  CIV.  P.  23(a).    In  addition,  the  Federal  Rules  of  Civil  Procedure  require  that  the 
defendants, at all times, have acted or refused to act in a manner generally applicable to the class.  
FED. R. CIV. P. 23(b)(2).  As indicated below, all of the requirements of Rule 23 are met in this 
case and the class should be certified. 
I.  EACH OF THE CLASSES IS SO NUMEROUS THAT THE JOINDER OF ALL 
MEMBERS IS IMPRACTICABLE 
3 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00957-JMS-MJD   Document 4   Filed 06/14/13   Page 4 of 11 PageID #: 83
  The first requirement for certification of a class is that the class must be so numerous that 
joinder of all members is impracticable.  See FED. R. CIV. P. 23(a)(1).  This does not impose an 
absolute numerical requirement for class certification.  Rather, courts must consider each case on 
its facts to determine the practicability of joining all class members.  See Swanson v. Am. 
Consumer Indus., Inc., 415 F.2d 1326 (7th Cir. 1969).  However, it has been held that “generally, 
a class of at least forty members will satisfy the requirement.”  McGarry v. Betcher, No. 4:08-cv-
0146, 2010 WL 1257446, at *3 (S.D. Ind. Mar. 24, 2010) (Young, J.) (citing cases); see also, 
e.g., EEOC v. Printing Indus. of Metro. D.C., Inc., 92 F.R.D. 51, 53 (D.D.C. 1981) (“[A]s few as 
25-30 class members should raise a presumption that joinder would be impracticable and that the 
class should be certified.”) (citing Newburg, Class Actions § 1105(b), at 174 (1977)). 
  While the precise size of each class in this case is not presently known (but will be 
ascertained through discovery), each class easily satisfies this threshold.  The fact that Ms. 
Steimel was on the waiting list for the CIH Waiver for twelve (12) or fifteen (15) years is strong 
evidence that Class A and Class B number in the thousands of persons.  Indeed, documentation 
available through the State’s website indicates that “5,938 individuals on the DD waiver waiting 
list  have  a  diagnosis  on  the  autism  spectrum,”  see  Indiana  Family  and  Social  Services 
Administration, Indiana Medicaid Waiver: the Community Integration and Habilitation Waiver, 
available  at  http://www.in.gov/fssa/files/CIH_WAIVER_PRESENTATION.pdf  (last  visited 
June 14, 2013), which is likely only a small portion of each of these classes.1  Similarly, Class C 
pertains to a waiver program (the A&D Waiver) that enrolls nearly fourteen thousand (14,000) 
persons.  On information and belief, a substantial number of these persons are developmentally 
disabled and subject to the challenged policy (and therefore within the class definition). 
                                                 
1   The cited document is undated.  However, it references the CIH Waiver, which did not 
bear that name until September 1, 2012.  It therefore appears likely that this document is recent. 
4 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00957-JMS-MJD   Document 4   Filed 06/14/13   Page 5 of 11 PageID #: 84
  Moreover, even were the classes not so sizeable, there are factors other than the number 
of class members to be considered on the issue of practicability of joinder:  “Among the factors 
to be considered along with the number of class members are geographic diversity, judicial 
economy,  and  the  ability  of  the  individual  class  members  to  institute  individual  lawsuits.”  
Tenants Associated for a Better Spaulding v. U.S. Dep’t of Hous. and Urban Dev., 97 F.R.D. 
726, 729 (N.D. Ill. 1983) (internal citations omitted); see also, e.g., Robidoux v. Celani, 987 F.2d 
931, 936 (2d Cir.1993) (Other “[r]elevant considerations include judicial economy arising from 
the avoidance of a multiplicity of actions, geographic dispersion of class members, financial 
resources of class members, the ability of claimants to institute individual suits, and requests for 
prospective injunctive relief which would involve future class members.”).  Thus, even “[a] 
relatively small group may form a class if other considerations make joinder impracticable.”  
Gaspar v. Linvatec Corp., 167 F.R.D. 51, 56 (N.D. Ill. 1996) (quoting Patrykus v. Gomilla, 121 
F.R.D. 357, 361 (N.D. Ill. 1988)).   
Of course, not only is each class in this case state-wide, but it also consists exclusively of 
seriously disabled persons who (a) have limited means so as to qualify for Medicaid assistance 
and (b) require significant services to avoid being institutionalized.  Clearly these are precisely 
the individuals for whom joinder is most impracticable.  In one case, for instance, the court 
found that putative class-members “may have no other means to exercise their rights because of 
inadequate resources to prosecute their own claims” when the class was comprised of mentally 
disabled individuals.  Cortigiano v. Oceanview Manor Home for Adults, 227 F.R.D. 194, 204–05 
(E.D.N.Y. 2005).  In Matyasovszky v. Housing Authority, 226 F.R.D. 35 (D. Conn. 2005), the 
court similarly relied on the fact that the putative class consisted of “low income, disabled, and in 
some cases homeless individuals” in order to conclude that joinder was altogether impracticable.  
5 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00957-JMS-MJD   Document 4   Filed 06/14/13   Page 6 of 11 PageID #: 85
Id. at 40–41.  And in Fields v. Maram, No. 04-C-0174, 2004 WL 1879997 (N.D. Ill. Aug. 17, 
2004), the court usefully  surveyed  a sampling  of similar cases in which the disabilities of 
putative class members factored into the numerosity calculus.  Said the court: 
Because the class members reside throughout the state, and because they are 
disabled and therefore are often of limited financial resources, joinder would be 
particularly difficult in this case.  See, e.g., Arenson [v. Whitehall Convalescent & 
Nursing Home, Inc.], 164 F.R.D. [659,] 663 [(N.D. Ill. 1996)] (“Class members 
who are residents of a nursing home may also lack the ability to pursue their 
claims individually.”); Raymond v. Rowland, 220 F.R.D. 173, 179 (D. Conn. 
2004) (finding, as to class of disabled recipients of state aid, that “[t]hese factors 
all speak in favor of certification: the Plaintiffs are dispersed throughout the state; 
they are by definition people of limited financial resources, they mostly lack the 
legal sophistication and financial wherewithal to bring individual suits”). 
 
Maram, 2004 WL 1879997, at *4.  See also, e.g., A.M.T. v. Gargano, No. 1:10-cv-0358, 2010 
WL 4860119, at *4 (S.D. Ind. Nov. 22, 2010) (Magnus-Stinson, J.) (“The medical and economic 
vulnerability of the putative class members makes joinder even more impracticable and further 
supports the Court’s finding that numerosity exists.”) (citation omitted). 
  Additionally, the court may also consider the numbers in the future class and draw an 
inference that joinder is impracticable.  See Lewis v. Gross, 663 F.Supp. 1164, 1169 (E.D.N.Y. 
1986).  In this case, both Class A and Class C contain future class-members, and will continue to 
grow in size.  Although the exact number of members of each class is currently unknown, it is 
likely that each class consists of thousands, if not tens of thousands, of individuals, and the 
precise number will be ascertained through the discovery process.  The defendants’ practices or 
policies presently at issue affect, and will continue to adversely affect, all of these individuals.  
And two (2) of the classes will continue to accumulate members.   Numerosity is present. 
II.  THERE ARE QUESTIONS OF LAW OR FACT COMMON TO EACH OF THE 
CLASSES 
 
6 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00957-JMS-MJD   Document 4   Filed 06/14/13   Page 7 of 11 PageID #: 86
  Rule 23(a)(2) of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure requires that there be questions of 
law or fact common to the class in order for a class action to be certified.  Several courts have 
held that the existence of a common scheme applied to all members of a class fulfills the 
requirement of this rule.  See, e.g., Fujishima v. Bd. of Educ., 460 F.2d 1355 (7th Cir. 1972); Like 
v. Carter, 448 F.2d 798 (8th Cir. 1971); Jones v. Blinzinger, 536 F.Supp. 1181, 1189 (N.D. Ind. 
1982).  In Like v. Carter, for instance, the Eighth Circuit Court of Appeals ruled that a state 
policy affecting all welfare recipients presented common questions of law, even though each 
member of the class presented minor deviations in fact.  See Carter, 448 F.2d at 798.  The 
Seventh Circuit applied a similar rule in Fujishima. 
  In this case, all class members are subject to the defendants’ various practices presently at 
issue.  The same questions exist for all class members:  
-  as to Class A, whether the challenged elimination of the wait-list for the waiver and 
corresponding priority criteria for obtaining waiver services violate the Americans 
with Disabilities Act of 1990 and/or the Rehabilitation Act of 1973. 
   
-  as  to  Class  B,  whether  the  failure  to  provide  for  an  appeals  process  upon  the 
termination of the wait-list for the waiver violates 42 U.S.C. § 1396a(a)(3). 
 
-  as to Class C, whether the elimination of persons’ eligibility for the waiver program 
violates the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 and/or the Rehabilitation Act of 
1973.  
 
There are, therefore, questions of law or fact common to the class.  Commonality, after all, only 
requires  that  defendants  “have  engaged  in  standardized  conduct  towards  members  of  the 
proposed class.”  Keele v. Wexler, 149 F.3d 589, 594 (7th Cir. 1998).  The State may not 
seriously contend that this requirement is not met. 
III.  THE CLAIMS OF THE NAMED PLAINTIFF ARE TYPICAL OF THE CLAIMS 
OF EACH OF THE CLASSES 
 
7 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00957-JMS-MJD   Document 4   Filed 06/14/13   Page 8 of 11 PageID #: 87
  Rule 23(a)(3) of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure requires that the claims of the 
representative parties be typical of those of the class.  As the U.S. Supreme Court has noted, this 
requirement is intertwined with the commonality requirement:   
[t]he commonality and typicality requirements of Rule 23(a) tend to merge.  Both 
serve as guideposts for determining whether under the particular circumstances 
maintenance of a class action is economical and whether the named plaintiff’s 
claim and the class claims are so inter-related that the interests of the class-
members will be fairly and adequately protected in their absence. 
 
Gen. Tel. Co. of Sw. v. Falcon, 457 U.S. 147, 157 n.13 (1982).  In order for this requirement to 
be met, there need not be identity of interest between the named plaintiff and the classes that she 
seeks to represent; rather, there need only be “sufficient homogeneity of interests.”  Sosna v. 
Iowa, 419 U.S. 393, 403 n.13 (1975).  Another view is that the typicality requirement is satisfied 
if the representative parties have no interests antagonistic to those of the class.  See Mersay v. 
First Republic Corp. of Am., 43 F.R.D. 465 (S.D.N.Y. 1965).  The fundamental inquiry is 
whether all members of the class would benefit in some way from a judgment favorable to the 
plaintiff.  See Ellis v. Naval Air Rework Facility, 404 F.Supp. 391, 396 (N.D. Calif. 1975), rev’d 
on other grounds, 608 F.2d 1308 (9th Cir. 1979). 
  Each of the putative classes meets these standards.  Ms. Steimel seeks to enjoin multiple 
policies of the State that have been generally applied to all members of the classes and that are 
alleged to violate the federal rights of Ms. Steimel and the putative classes.  All members of the 
class would benefit in some way from a judgment favorable to the plaintiffs in that all class 
members  would  be  receive  protection  from  these  policies,  and  will  be  permitted  access  to 
necessary services in the least restrictive setting appropriate to their needs (or, in the case of 
Class B, access to an appeal mechanism to challenge the State’s actions).  The named plaintiff is, 
8 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00957-JMS-MJD   Document 4   Filed 06/14/13   Page 9 of 11 PageID #: 88
therefore, typical of the classes she seeks to represent.  See, e.g., Rosario v. Livaditis, 963 F.2d 
1013, 1018 (7th Cir. 1992); Koos v. First Nat’l Bank of Peoria, 496 F.2d 1162 (7th Cir. 1974). 
IV.  THE  NAMED  PLAINTIFF  AND  CLASS  COUNSEL  WILL  FAIRLY  AND 
ADEQUATELY PROTECT THE INTERESTS OF EACH OF THE CLASSES  
 
  Rule  23(a)(4)  of  the  Federal  Rules  of  Civil  Procedure  requires  that  the  class 
representative’s interests be such that she can and will vigorously pursue the classes’ interests as 
well as her own.  See, e.g., Hohman v. Packard Instrument Co., 399 F.2d 711 (7th Cir. 1968).  
Ms.  Steimel  is  represented  by  counsel  skilled  and  experienced  in  this  type  of  litigation.  
Moreover, the relief that she seeks “is not inconsistent in any way with the interests of the 
members of the class.”  Jones, 536 F.Supp. at 1190.  Likewise, Ms. Steimel has a stake in these 
proceedings that will “insure diligent and thorough prosecution of the litigation.”  Rodriquez v. 
Swank, 318 F.Supp. 289, 294 (N.D. Ill. 1970), aff’d, 496 F.2d 1110 (7th Cir. 1974).  The plaintiff 
is an adequate class representative and her counsel is adequate class counsel.2 
V.  THE FURTHER REQUIREMENTS OF RULE 23(b)(2) ARE MET IN THIS CASE 
WITH RESPECT TO EACH OF THE CLASSES 
 
  The final rule for class certification is stated in Rule 23(b)(2) of the Federal Rules of 
Civil Procedure.  In order to meet the requirements of Rule 23(b)(2), the party who opposes the 
class must have “acted or refused to act on grounds generally applicable to the class, thereby 
making appropriate final injunctive or corresponding declaratory relief with respect to the class 
as a whole.”  This is not a difficult standard to meet in a case such as this one, where the 
plaintiffs challenge governmental policies of general applicability.  After all, “Rule 23(b)(2) was 
drafted specifically to facilitate relief in civil rights suits.  Most class actions in the constitutional 
and civil rights areas seek primarily declaratory and injunctive relief on behalf of the class and 
                                                 
2   Undersigned counsel should therefore be appointed class counsel pursuant to Rule 23(g) 
of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure. 
9 
 

Case 1:13-cv-00957-JMS-MJD   Document 4   Filed 06/14/13   Page 10 of 11 PageID #: 89
therefore readily satisfy Rule 23(b)(2) class action criteria.”  Tyson v. Grant County Sheriff, No. 
1:07-cv-0010,  2007  WL  1395563,  *5  (N.D.  Ind.  May  9,  2007)  (quoting  A.  CONTE  &  H. 
NEWBERG, 8 NEWBERG ON CLASS ACTIONS, § 25.20 (4th ed. 2002)).  Consequently, “[t]he 
requirements of the rule are . . . given a liberal construction in civil rights suits.”  John Does 1-
100 v. Boyd, 613 F.Supp. 1514, 1528 (D. Minn. 1985) (citing Coley v. Clinton, 635 F.2d 1364, 
1379 (8th Cir. 1980)).  In this case, the allegedly illegal actions of the State and its violations of 
federal law have detrimentally affected and will continue to detrimentally affect the named 
plaintiff as well as the members of the putative classes.  The plaintiff seeks to enjoin these 
unlawful actions.  The State has therefore acted or refused to act on grounds generally applicable 
to each class, and the requirements of Rule 23(b)(2) are therefore met. 
CONCLUSION 
For the above reasons, this case should be certified as a class action pursuant to Rule 
23(a) and (b)(2) with three (3) classes defined as indicated. 
 
 
 
_/s/ Gavin M. Rose______________
